page.title: 11A GRETTON FARM 1945 AND 1985
page.content: Machinery used on farms has developed greatly since 1945. Grass was cut by mowing machines pulled by two horses, the farmer sitting on a metal seat. After a fortnight in the sun, and being turned occasionally, the hay was put into haycocks, which were later made into stacks. So, too, with harvesting. Self-binders cut the corn and tied it into sheaves, which were made into stooks of eight sheaves to dry out. They were then stored in Dutch barns until a threshing machine visited the farm to thresh the wheat and bale the straw. Men, women and children all helped in the hay and corn. All cows were milked by hand, the milk sieved and cooled, and delivered from a churn. Forty years later, grass is cut and put straight into siloes, corn is dealt with by combined harvesters, and cows are milked by machines.
